repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This isn't exactly the same usage but I think is more idiomatic

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,67 +104,62 @@ def make_command_file(path_to_debug_info, prefix_code='',
 
     return tempfilename
 
-usage = "Usage: cygdb [options] [PATH [-- GDB_ARGUMENTS]]"
 
-def main(path_to_debug_info=None, gdb_argv=None, no_import=False):
+def main():
     """
     Start the Cython debugger. This tells gdb to import the Cython and Python
     extensions (libcython.py and libpython.py) and it enables gdb's pending
     breakpoints.
-
-    path_to_debug_info is the path to the Cython build directory
-    gdb_argv is the list of options to gdb
-    no_import tells cygdb whether it should import debug information
     """
-    parser = optparse.OptionParser(usage=usage)
-    parser.add_option("--gdb-executable",
+    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
+        prog="cygdb",
+        description="Cython debugger",
+    )
+    parser.add_argument("gdb_argv", nargs="*",
+                        help="arguments to forward to gdb; specified after --")
+    parser.add_argument("--build_dir", default=os.curdir,
+                        help="directory containing cython_build/ files")
+    parser.add_argument("--no_import", default=False,
+                        help="whether cygdb should import debug information")
+    parser.add_argument("--gdb-executable",
         dest="gdb", default='gdb',
         help="gdb executable to use [default: gdb]")
-    parser.add_option("--verbose", "-v",
+    parser.add_argument("--verbose", "-v",
         dest="verbosity", action="count", default=0,
         help="Verbose mode. Multiple -v options increase the verbosity")
-    parser.add_option("--skip-interpreter",
+    parser.add_argument("--skip-interpreter",
                       dest="skip_interpreter", default=False, action="store_true",
                       help="Do not automatically point GDB to the same interpreter "
                            "used to generate debugging information")
 
-    (options, args) = parser.parse_args()
-    if path_to_debug_info is None:
-        if len(args) > 1:
-            path_to_debug_info = args[0]
-        else:
-            path_to_debug_info = os.curdir
-
-    if gdb_argv is None:
-        gdb_argv = args[1:]
+    parsed = parser.parse_args()
+    path_to_debug_info = parsed.build_dir
+    gdb_argv = parsed.gdb_argv
+    no_import = parsed.no_import
 
     if path_to_debug_info == '--':
         no_import = True
 
     logging_level = logging.WARN
-    if options.verbosity == 1:
+    if parsed.verbosity == 1:
         logging_level = logging.INFO
-    if options.verbosity >= 2:
+    if parsed.verbosity >= 2:
         logging_level = logging.DEBUG
     logging.basicConfig(level=logging_level)
 
     skip_interpreter = options.skip_interpreter

comment_data.body: I am for this change since this is `main()` function but not sure whether it won't break somewhere outside cython. Maybe I would go with it but I would like to see someone else opinion...

comment_data.body: Is it possible that parameter `build_dir` will contain `--`. I suppose `no_import` variable is controlled by `--no-import` argument, so this can be removed.

comment_data.body: Moreover, the arguments are changed. Again, I like new version but it can break users so I think another opinion is needed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,67 +104,62 @@ def make_command_file(path_to_debug_info, prefix_code='',
 
     return tempfilename
 
-usage = "Usage: cygdb [options] [PATH [-- GDB_ARGUMENTS]]"
 
-def main(path_to_debug_info=None, gdb_argv=None, no_import=False):
+def main():

comment_data.body:
TBH — and this is _heavy_ bikeshedding, admittedly — I really dislike `parsed` as a name for the results of `ArgumentParser.parse_args()`.

`parsed` represents the **state** of the results, not the **contents**, which is focusing on the wrong thing. The fact that the contents were _parsed_ is irrelevant compared to the question of **what the contents _are_**. But the name doesn't even _hint_ at that.

`options` is still pretty common when using `argparse`, same as it was with `optparse`. But if you don't like `options`... well, if you call a parser's `parse_args()` method, it seems pretty tautological what that would produce: `args`.

(You even label them exactly that way on line 152.):

```python3
logger.debug("args = %r", parsed)
```

So even your own code is subconsciously agreeing that `parsed` should be named `args`. :wink:

comment_data.body: Sure no strong attachment to `parsed`. The downside to `args` is that it conflicts with the pdb args command, so you can more easily get confused when debugging (at least I do). Happy to revert back to options

For better name consistency:
```suggestion
    parser.add_argument("--build-dir", default=os.curdir,
```

comment_data.body:
I am thinking about this argument. Do we need it? I think that because `--no_import` should be used only and only when `--build_dir` is not specified and vise versa. 

I propose just to set `no_import` to `True` when `--build-dir` is not specified.

This will avoid code managing the case when both arguments are specified (PR currently does not manages it). Moreover, current master version has same semantics.

comment_data.body:
:+1: Thanks, `options` makes sense to me.

It struck me after posting my original comment: _another_ reason to avoid `parsed` is that having `parsed` and `parser` in the same scope (differing by only the last letter) feels like a recipe for long-term maintainability issues. Someone down the road could _easily_ confuse the two.

commit.message: Upgrade cygdb from optparse to argparse

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Upgrade cygdb from optparse to argparse
